name: Somali
description: Somali is an Afroasiatic language belonging to the Cushitic branch. It is spoken primarily in Greater Somalia, and by the Somali diaspora as a mother tongue. Somali is an official language in both Somalia and Ethiopia, and serves as a national language in Djibouti. It is also a recognised minority language in Kenya. The Somali language is officially written with the Latin alphabet, although the Arabic script and several Somali scripts like Osmanya, Kaddare and the Borama script are informally used.

name: South African English
description: South African English is the set of English language dialects native to South Africans.

name: Southern French
description: Meridional French, also referred to as Francitan, is the regional variant of the French language spoken in the area of Marseille, Avignon and Toulouse. It is influenced by the Occitan language.

name: Southern Vietnamese
description: Vietnamese is an Austroasiatic language primarily spoken in Vietnam where it is the official language. It belongs to the Vietic subgroup of the Austroasiatic language family. Vietnamese is spoken natively by around 86 million people, and as a second language by 11 million people, several times as many as the rest of the Austroasiatic family combined. It is the native language of ethnic Vietnamese (Kinh), as well as the second or first language for other ethnicities of Vietnam, and used by Vietnamese diaspora in the world.

name: Stockholm Swedish
description: Stockholm dialects are the forms of Swedish spoken in Stockholm. An exact definition encompassing its peculiarities is hard to find, as a cosmopolitan culture and early adoption infers a great variety of international influences that are then spread to the rest of Sweden, and, as Stockholm is a highly urbanized area, the dialects of Stockholm are more likely to undergo rapid changes than dialects spoken in rural areas.

name: Sundanese Indonesian
description: Sundanese Indonesian is the variety of Indonesian heavily influenced by Sundanese linguistic patterns, spoken primarily in West Java. It features distinctive pronunciation characteristics, Sundanese loanwords, and grammatical structures that reflect Sundanese cultural concepts, making it distinct from standard Indonesian.

name: Swahili
description: Swahili, also known as Kiswahili as it is referred to in the Swahili language, is a Bantu language originally spoken by the Swahili people, who are found primarily in Tanzania, Kenya, and Mozambique. Estimates of the number of Swahili speakers, including both native and second-language speakers, vary widely. They generally range from 150 million to 200 million; with most of its native speakers residing in Tanzania and Kenya.

name: Swedish
description: Swedish is a North Germanic language from the Indo-European language family, spoken predominantly in Sweden and parts of Finland. It has at least 10 million native speakers, making it the fourth most spoken Germanic language, and the first among its type in the Nordic countries overall.

name: Swiss French
description: Swiss French is the variety of French spoken in the French-speaking area of Switzerland known as Romandy. French is one of the four official languages of Switzerland, the others being German, Italian, and Romansch. In 2020 around 2 million people, or 22.8% of the population, in Switzerland spoke French as their primary language, and 28% of the population used French most often at work.

name: São Paulo Portuguese
description: São Paulo Portuguese is the variety of Brazilian Portuguese spoken in São Paulo city, Brazil's largest metropolis. This variety is characterized by distinctive pronunciation features, rapid speech patterns, and vocabulary influenced by the city's diverse immigrant population, making it a reference point for urban Brazilian Portuguese.

name: Taiwan Mandarin
description: Taiwanese Mandarin, frequently referred to as Guoyu or Huayu in Mandarin, is the variety of Mandarin spoken in Taiwan. A large majority of the Taiwanese population is fluent in Mandarin, though many also speak a variety of Min Chinese known as Taiwanese Hokkien, which has had a significant influence on the Mandarin spoken on the island.

name: Tamil
description: Tamil (தமிழ், Tamiḻ, pronounced [t̪amiɻ], is a Dravidian language natively spoken by the Tamil people of South Asia. It is one of the longest-surviving classical languages in the world, attested since c. 300 BCE.

name: Tamil Hindi
description: Tamil Hindi is the variety of Hindi spoken with heavy Tamil linguistic influence, common among Tamil speakers when communicating in Hindi. It features distinctive pronunciation patterns where retroflex sounds are often replaced, specific intonation borrowed from Tamil, and substrate influence in vocabulary and grammar.

name: Thai
description: Thai, or Central Thai, is a Tai language of the Kra–Dai language family spoken by the Central Thai, Mon, Lao Wiang, and Phuan people in Central Thailand and the vast majority of Thai Chinese enclaves throughout the country. It is the sole official language of Thailand.

name: Transylvanian Romanian
description: Transylvanian Romanian is the variety of Romanian spoken in Transylvania, central Romania. This dialect has been influenced by Hungarian and German due to the region's multiethnic history and features distinctive pronunciation patterns, vocabulary, and expressions that distinguish it from Wallachian Romanian.

name: Turkish
description: Turkish is the most widely spoken of the Turkic languages with around 90 million speakers. It is the national language of Turkey and one of two official languages of Cyprus. Significant smaller groups of Turkish speakers also exist in Germany, Austria, Bulgaria, North Macedonia, Greece, other parts of Europe, the South Caucasus, and some parts of Central Asia, Iraq, and Syria. Turkish is the 18th-most spoken language in the world.

name: Turku Finnish
description: Turku Finnish is the variety of Finnish spoken in Turku and southwestern Finland. As Finland's former capital, this variety has historical significance and features distinctive pronunciation patterns and vocabulary that reflect the region's Swedish cultural influence and maritime character.

name: Tuscan Italian
description: Tuscan Italian is the variety of Italian spoken in Tuscany, which historically formed the basis of standard Italian literature and language. Modern Tuscan features distinctive pronunciation characteristics including the famous 'gorgia toscana' and vocabulary that preserves archaic Italian forms, making it recognizable throughout Italy.

name: Ukrainian
description: Ukrainian is an East Slavic language, spoken primarily in Ukraine. It is the first (native) language of a large majority of Ukrainians.

name: Urdu
description: Urdu is an Indo-Aryan language spoken chiefly in South Asia. It is the national language and lingua franca of Pakistan. In India, it is an Eighth Schedule language, the status and cultural heritage of which are recognised by the Constitution of India. It also has an official status in several Indian states.

name: Venetian Italian
description: Venetian Italian is the variety of Italian spoken in the Veneto region, heavily influenced by the Venetian language substrate. This variety features distinctive pronunciation patterns, vocabulary borrowings from Venetian, and reflects the region's unique cultural and historical identity within Italy.

name: Venezuelan Spanish
description: Venezuelan Spanish is the variety of Spanish spoken in Venezuela.

name: Vietnamese
description: Vietnamese is an Austroasiatic language primarily spoken in Vietnam where it is the official language. It belongs to the Vietic subgroup of the Austroasiatic language family. Vietnamese is spoken natively by around 86 million people, and as a second language by 11 million people, several times as many as the rest of the Austroasiatic family combined. It is the native language of ethnic Vietnamese (Kinh), as well as the second or first language for other ethnicities of Vietnam, and used by Vietnamese diaspora in the world.

name: Welsh
description: Welsh is a Celtic language of the Brittonic subgroup that is native to the Welsh people. Welsh is spoken natively in Wales by about 18% of the population, by some in England, and in Y Wladfa.

name: Welsh English
description: Welsh English comprises the dialects of English spoken by Welsh people. The dialects are significantly influenced by Welsh grammar and often include words derived from Welsh. In addition to the distinctive words and grammar, a variety of accents are found across Wales, including those of North Wales, the Cardiff dialect, the South Wales Valleys and West Wales.

name: Western Finnish
description: Western Finnish refers to the varieties of Finnish spoken in western Finland, including regions like Ostrobothnia. These dialects feature distinctive pronunciation patterns, vocabulary, and grammatical features that distinguish them from standard Finnish, often showing Swedish influence due to historical bilingualism in the region.

name: Yorkshire English
description: Yorkshire dialect, also known as Yorkshire English, Broad Yorkshire, Tyke, or Yorkie, is a grouping of several regionally neighbouring dialects of English spoken in Yorkshire. Yorkshire experienced drastic dialect levelling in the 20th century, eroding many traditional features, though variation and even innovations persist, at both the regional and sub-regional levels. Organisations such as the Yorkshire Dialect Society and the East Riding Dialect Society exist to promote the survival of the more traditional features.

name: Zagreb Croatian
description: Zagreb Croatian is the prestige variety of Croatian spoken in Croatia's capital city. As the standard form of the language, it serves as the basis for Croatian media, education, and official communication. This variety forms the foundation of modern standard Croatian and influences Croatian language instruction.

name: Zealand Danish
description: Zealand Danish is the variety of Danish spoken on the island of Zealand, including Copenhagen. As the prestige dialect, it forms the basis of standard Danish and is characterized by specific pronunciation patterns and vocabulary that serve as the model for Danish media, education, and official communication.
